poem:
**Boreas' Breath**

In Boreas' breath,  
the shivering trees  
whisper, cloak-bound,  
the chill, blue tales  
of ships unmoored,  
skyward flights  
on wild wings,  
beyond the cloak,  
shell-sound echoes—  
storm-savior  
to silent cities;  
wind-carved chisel  
against the first  
oak leaves of  
winter's imminent  
kiss,  
and the swirling  
dance of shadows.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Weatherwatch: Myths behind the capricious god of the north wind The ancient Greeks personified the north wind as the god Boreas, and his chill breezes were a sign of the imminent arrival of winter. Boreas was depicted as a winged man in a billowing cloak holding a conch shell. He had a notoriously bad temper that produced violent storms, and he shipwrecked Odysseus and Hercules. But in some cities, Boreas was a hero and saviour.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Weatherwatch: Myths behind the capricious god of the north wind The ancient Greeks personified the north wind as the god Boreas, and his chill breezes were a sign of the imminent arrival of winter. Boreas was depicted as a winged man in a billowing cloak holding a conch shell. He had a notoriously bad temper that produced violent storms, and he shipwrecked Odysseus and Hercules. But in some cities, Boreas was a hero and saviour.
